text:
1. Geographic Setting - 
 1.1 Location and Access  
 The Mt Marmion Project is located in the Menzies District in the North Coolgardie Mineral Field 
 (Figure 1). The Project strikes north-northeast and is located approximately 55km west of the 
 Copperfield Mining Centre. The Project lies within the Marmion (2839) 1:100,000 sheet. The Mt 
 Marmion Project is accessible from Menzies by travelling 130km along the well maintained unsealed 
 Sandstone Road to Perrinvale Pastoral Station and then approximately 20 kilometres southwest on 
 unsealed pastoral station tracks. 
 1.2 Land Status and Usage 
 The northern half of the Mt Marmion Project lies on the Perrinvale Pastoral Station, whereas the 
 southern half of the Project overlies vacant crown land. 
 A search of the Native Title Register shows that the Project is subject to the following native title claim

12.text: The southern half of the Mt Marmion Project overlies the Evanston Shear Zone, whereas the northern

13.text: half of the Project overlies the north trending contractional zone that links the Edale and Evanston

text:
The southern half of the Mt Marmion Project overlies the Evanston Shear Zone, whereas the northern 
 half of the Project overlies the north trending contractional zone that links the Edale and Evanston

22.text: terrane. D1 north-south compression produced low-angle thrusts, a gently dipping foliation, and tight to

23.text: isoclinal folds. D2 east-west shortening produced north-trending macroscopic upright folds with a weak

24.text: axial-planar foliation. D3 progressive, inhomogeneous east-west shortening produced northwest-

25.text: trending sinistral shear zones and northeast-trending dextral shear zones that formed regional-scale

26.text: arcuate structures. Post-D3 structures include widespread east-, east-northeast-, and northeast-trending

27.text: brittle faults or fractures, some of which are filled by quartz veins or mafic dykes.

29.text: Although the South Cookwell greenstone belt has been explored to some extent for gold, nickel, and

30.text: base metals, no major mineral deposits have been identified.

text:
terrane. D1 north-south compression produced low-angle thrusts, a gently dipping foliation, and tight to 
 isoclinal folds. D2 east-west shortening produced north-trending macroscopic upright folds with a weak 
 axial-planar foliation. D3 progressive, inhomogeneous east-west shortening produced northwest-
 trending sinistral shear zones and northeast-trending dextral shear zones that formed regional-scale 
 arcuate structures. Post-D3 structures include widespread east-, east-northeast-, and northeast-trending 
 brittle faults or fractures, some of which are filled by quartz veins or mafic dykes. 
 Although the South Cookwell greenstone belt has been explored to some extent for gold, nickel, and 
 base metals, no major mineral deposits have been identified.

11.text: Mineral Exploration Report for the Period 1 November 1994 to 31 October 1995. Battle Mountain Inc.

13.text: Work carried out consisted of soil sampling (167 samples), stream sediment sampling (18 samples),

14.text: and rock chip sampling (14 samples). No significant results were returned from this exploration. All of

15.text: this work was completed in the southern half of E29/205, which does not overlie the Mt Marmion

 the Year Ending 15 May 1998. 
 Work completed consisted of reconnaissance prospecting and 400m x 400m loam sampling. No visible 
 gold was located and only one of 6 rock chip samples collected returned anomalous gold (4.66g/t Au). 
 Area of work is to the south of the Mt Marmion Project area.

35.text: Aerial photography for the Mt Marmion Project area was acquired from the Department of Land

36.text: Information. Unfortunately these photos were not in digital format so they had to be scanned as TIFF

37.text: images. Each photo has to be individually ground referenced so it can be imported into Mapinfo. At

38.text: present several attempts have been made to ground reference these photos with limited success due to

39.text: projection issues and a lack of obvious reference points distributed across the photos. Further attempts

40.text: to ground reference these photos will be undertaken during the next reporting period, however it is

41.text: envisaged that considerable errors are likely.

text:
period and will be completed during the second half of 2007 once all data from the regional auger soil 
 survey (discussed in Section 3.4) is received. 
 Aerial photography for the Mt Marmion Project area was acquired from the Department of Land 
 Information. Unfortunately these photos were not in digital format so they had to be scanned as TIFF 
 images. Each photo has to be individually ground referenced so it can be imported into Mapinfo. At 
 present several attempts have been made to ground reference these photos with limited success due to 
 projection issues and a lack of obvious reference points distributed across the photos. Further attempts 
 to ground reference these photos will be undertaken during the next reporting period, however it is 
 envisaged that considerable errors are likely.

17.text: in the silica caprock confirm the presence of cumulate-textured ultramafic rocks. The interpreted

18.text: footwall contact of each ultramafic unit was checked for gossans indicative of massive nickel sulphide

19.text: mineralisation, however none were found. All of the ultramafic units located are strata bounded on at

20.text: least one side by banded iron-formation that forms pronounced ridges that shed lag over the

21.text: preferentially weathered ultramafic rock. Auger soil sampling will be utilised to assess the nickel

22.text: exploration potential of these units. Other lithologies observed within the Project area include

23.text: pyroxenite, komatiitic basalt, gabbro, banded iron-formation, chert, shale, granite, and gneiss.

26.text: The Geoscience Australia 400m spaced Barlee aeromagnetic data set and Mindax Resources Limited

11.text: The topography of the Mt Marmion Project area is dominated by generally north-south striking bucky

12.text: quartz and banded iron formation ridges. These ridges are steep (limiting vehicle access) and scree lag

13.text: over the adjacent colluvium and alluvium. Of particular interest were the areas of silica capped

14.text: ultramafic rocks. These silicous outcrops commonly occur over cumulate-textured ultramafic rocks that

text:
The topography of the Mt Marmion Project area is dominated by generally north-south striking bucky 
 quartz and banded iron formation ridges. These ridges are steep (limiting vehicle access) and scree lag 
 over the adjacent colluvium and alluvium. Of particular interest were the areas of silica capped 
 ultramafic rocks. These silicous outcrops commonly occur over cumulate-textured ultramafic rocks that

28.text: produce regional aeromagnetic images of the Project area. A suite of images containing various sun

29.text: angles and filters has been produced in ECW format for import into Mapinfo (Figure 8). An

30.text: interpretive geology plan based on these aeromagnetic images was commenced during the reporting

10.text: the spectral analysis is to determine the effectiveness of the auger soil sampling by identify transported

11.text: and non-transported samples using the analysis of kaolinite crystallinity. Secondary benefits of this

12.text: technique include identifying the main mineralogy of samples to help identify primary rock types and

13.text: possible mapping of regional metamorphism, oxidation, and alteration. Samples will be selectively sent

14.text: to Ultra Trace in Perth for gold analysis based on the results of this work.

text:
the spectral analysis is to determine the effectiveness of the auger soil sampling by identify transported 
 and non-transported samples using the analysis of kaolinite crystallinity. Secondary benefits of this 
 technique include identifying the main mineralogy of samples to help identify primary rock types and 
 possible mapping of regional metamorphism, oxidation, and alteration. Samples will be selectively sent 
 to Ultra Trace in Perth for gold analysis based on the results of this work.
